III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code &
MISEP 6.14 Caseload, Foster Care Workers (Commitment
Section
60).
Description
(a) (a) 95% of foster care caseworkers shall have a
caseload of no more than 15 children.
Violation Potential Rule or Statue Violation.
Type
Allegation Agency staff were carrying inappropriate caseload weights.
Investigation On 10/3/2022 I reviewed the complaint, which indicated all
workers, including newer workers were being forced to carry
caseloads of 16-17. The complaint did not identify whether this
was foster case or adoption staff.
I was unable to interview the complainant due to the complainant
being anonymous.
Administrator 1:
Chief Administrator 1(here on referred to as Administrator 1) was
interviewed by me via telephone of 10/5/2022; and onsite on
10/12/2022. Administrator 1 reported she is actually the agency’s
Vice President of Child Welfare for the Northern Region. She
began oversight of Ennis-Port Huron on 7/25/2022, due to a
staffing shortage.
Administrator 1 reported the agency does not have workers out of
compliance with caseload sizes. She inquired whether this
complaint was old. She surmised it must have generated from a
disgruntle fired staff, and due to the staffing issues, this agency
had experienced some months ago. She reported when she took
oversight of this site, two of the site’s foster care supervisors had
resigned on 6/3/2022 and 6/23/2022; they were down two foster
care workers, and the site was without a program director. She
said the new program director (the site’s chief administrator)
started on 10/10/2022, a foster care worker and foster care
supervisor were hired on 9/15/2022; and an internal worker was
promoted to a foster care supervisor position. She denied there
being a time the agency was out of caseload compliance, but
admitted the agency is still not fully staffed. She reported the
agency is down a foster care worker due to a foster care worker’s
promotion to foster care supervisor. This latter foster care
2

supervisor (who does not have any staff currently under her
supervision) is supervising nine of the agency’s 51 cases.
Administrator 1 reported during Ennis- Port Huron’s staffing
shortage Ennis- Saginaw stepped in and assisted with caseloads.
Ennis Saginaw had and continues to service 11 of their cases.
The remaining cases are split between three foster care workers
(15, 5, and 14 respectively) and a foster care supervisor who is
carrying two cases. Administrator 1 provided a caseload list which
showed the break down.
Staff Interviews:
I interviewed Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4, Staff 5, and Staff 7 onsite on
10/12/2022. I interviewed Staff 6 by telephone while I was onsite
on 10/12/2022, and I interviewed Staff 8 by telephone on
10/17/2022.
• Staff 2 is a foster care supervisor. She reported promotion
to this position in August of 2022. She is carrying a
caseload of nine and is currently not supervising any staff.
She reported a caseload of 13 prior to the recent adoption
of four of the children who were on her caseload. She
denied ever having 16 or more cases, or an awareness of
any of her coworkers having 16 or more cases. Nor was
she knowledgeable of a new worker having more than
three or five cases.
• Staff 4, Staff 6, and Staff 8 are foster care workers. They
reported caseload sizes of 14, 14, and 13 respectively.
➢ Staff 4 reported employment with the agency since
January 2022. She reported a progression of cases
after several weeks in the child welfare training
institute (CWTI) from three to five. She said she has
had a caseload as high as 15.
➢ Staff 6 reported employment with the agency since
December 2019. She reported there was a brief
period starting in July 2022 that her total caseload
size was 16, but two of those cases, which were
permanent ward cases were assigned to her
supervisor. She reported that technically the cases
were still assigned to her in MISACWIS, but the
supervisor covered them with her assistance. The
cases were transferred to another worker a couple of
weeks ago.
3

➢ Staff 8 is a new foster care worker as of 9/15/2022.
She reported getting three cases after the third week
of her CWTI training and she has 13 cases currently.
• Staff 3 and Staff 5 are adoption workers; and Staff 7 is a
licensing worker. They have been employed with the
agency two, two and five years respectively. None of these
staff reported an awareness of any foster care workers
having to carry 16 plus cases.
Documents Reviewed:
• A Caseload list, which showed the caseload breakdown as
described above. This list also showed Administrator 1 and
PD XX were supervising staff.
Analysis The evidence showed foster worker caseload sizes are currently
in compliance. There may have been a very brief period of time
that one worker had a caseload of 16 due to high staff losses
between July 2022 and September 2022. This was a challenging
time for the agency, and it sought the aid and assistance of
personnel from its sister agencies during that time; and as
previously stated the agency is compliant with this statue.
Conclusion Violation Not Established.
Rule Code &
MISEP 6.15 Caseload, Adoption Workers (Commitment
Section
61).
Description
(a) 95% of adoption caseworkers shall have a
caseload of no more than 15 children.
Violation Potential Rule or Statue Violation.
Type
Allegation Agency staff were carrying inappropriate caseload sizes.
Investigation On 10/3/2022 I reviewed the complaint, which indicated all
indicated all workers, including newer workers were being forced
to carry caseloads of 16-17. The complaint did not identify
whether this was foster case or adoption staff.
I was unable to interview the complainant due to the complainant
being anonymous.
4

Staff Interviews
I interviewed Administrator 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4, Staff 5, and
Staff 7 onsite on 10/12/2022. I interviewed Staff 6 by telephone
while I was onsite on 10/12/2022; and I interviewed Staff 8 by
telephone on 10/17/2022.
• Administrator 1 was not aware of any adoption case close
noncompliance. She acknowledged that the agency had
experienced significant staffing issues between July and
September of 2022, due to a number of supervisors and
workers leaving the agency in addition the agency’s
program director.
• Staff 3 and Staff 5 are agency adoption workers.
➢ Staff 3 reported a caseload size of 15 since July
2022. She reported that prior to the July date she
had 13 cases.
➢ Staff 6 reported a caseload size of 14 but added
there was approximately a month where she had 16
cases after the foster care/adoption supervisor, who
was carrying those two cases left the agency.
• Staff 7 is a licensing worker, and Staff 2, Staff 4, Staff 6,
and Staff 8 are foster care staff. None of these staff were
aware of adoption workers carrying caseloads as high as
indicated in the complaint.
Documents Reviewed:
• A Caseload list, which showed the caseload breakdown as
described above. This list also showed Administrator 1 and
PD XX were supervising staff.
Analysis The evidence showed adoption workers’ caseload sizes are
currently in compliance. There may have been a time due to high
staff losses that one adoption worker had a caseload of 16. This
was a challenging time for the agency, and it sought the aid and
assistance of personnel from its sister agencies during that time.
Since that one brief episode the agency’s adoption worker
caseload sizes have been and continue to be in compliance.
Conclusion Violation Not Established.
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all of the following activities:
5

(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care. Social
service workers shall work directly with the children, their families,
and other relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service plans for the
children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statue Violation.
Type
Allegation Due to agency staff carrying inappropriate foster care caseload
weights it may have caused late service plans, missed home visits
and a missed court hearing.
Investigation On 10/3/2022 I reviewed the complaint which indicated
Administrator 1 was supposed to have attended a court hearing
for a supervisor and she missed the hearing causing the judge to
be upset. Further information surrounding this allegation was not
reported in the complaint; and the complainant was anonymous.
Staff Interviews:
I interviewed Administrator 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4, Staff 5, and
Staff 7 onsite on 10/12/2022. I interviewed Staff 6 by telephone
while I was onsite on 10/12/2022; and I interviewed Staff 8 by
telephone on 10/17/2022.
None of the staff interviewed reported there being an issue with
workers missing or being late with reports or not completing home
visits.
With the exception of Administrator 1 and Staff 5, none of the
other staff persons interviewed reported having direct knowledge
of a missed court date.
➢ Administrator 1 reported she was to have attended an
August 2022 court hearing for the foster care supervisor,
Staff 2. Administrator 1 missed the hearing because she
had the incorrect date. She reported no one contacted her
from the court, she was advised by PD XX. She contacted
the court and explained the error. She admitted the court
was upset, reportedly because a prior worker (who was
fired from the agency) had missed a prior hearing.
Administrator 1 said the court understood and advised not
to miss another hearing. She reported Staff 2 attended the
next hearing and there were no other issues.
➢ Staff 5 reported Staff 2 was on vacation and Staff 2’s
supervisor, Administrator 1 was supposed to attend the
court hearing, but missed it. Staff 5 reported being at the
hearing as the adoption worker, but she was not sure why
Administrator 1 was not present. She said the judge was
6

upset, but “We worked it out and the hearing got reset”.
Staff 5 did not advise why she did not call Administrator 1
related to the hearing.
Documents Reviewed:
• Ennis-Port Huron Organizational Chart as of 10/10/2022
which showed:
➢ Administrator 1 as the Vice President for the
Northern Region; and Administrator ZZ as the
program director.
➢ Director ZZZ as the director of Ennis- Saginaw
whose office is covering 11 of Port- Huron’s cases
➢ Staff 2 as one of two Foster Care
Manager/Supervisor supervised by Administrator 1.
➢ The other supervisor as Staff 9 who supervises,
Staff 4, Staff 6, and Staff 8.
➢ The Adoption team under Adoption Program
Manager, Staff 10 who supervises Staff 3, Staff 5,
Adoption Supervisor 11 and one other adoption staff.
➢ The Licensing/Certification team under Supervisor,
Staff 12 who supervises, Staff 7 and one other
certification worker.
• MISACWIS case records, for eight of the 45 cases listed on
the caseload list provided to me, with respect to service
plans completion, foster care/caregiver home visits and
worker supervisor meetings. No areas of noncompliance
were observed related to these service standards.
• An 8/15/2022 11:30am email from Administrator 1 to a
person at St. Clair County court that indicated:
➢ She received information from PD XX that she was
apprised the court needed contact information on her
which she provided in this email.
➢ Additionally, that she will be in Port Huron on Tuesday and
Wednesday of this week and asking to possibly to see the
judge on either of those days. Administrator 1 also gave an
explanation as to as to how/why the court hearing was
missed. That being, that it was on her calendar for
Tuesday instead of Monday.
➢ She apologized to the court, and advised that if the Ennis
worker, who was at the hearing had called her, she could
have still gotten on for the hearing, but she took
responsibility for having the wrong date.
➢ She advised that she was working on getting Port Huron
back to standards, as the agency has had many staff who
7

had left, and she was helping to fill in as director and
supervisor until the agency gets fully staffed.
Analysis There is insufficient evidence to support the allegations, or that the
workers were not working directly with children, their families, and
other relevant individuals related to the development
implementation, and review of service plans for the children and
their families.
The missed court date was due to a date error by Administrator 1,
but the adoption worker was in attendance. The agency worked
the matter out with the court.
Conclusion Violation Not Established.
Rule Code & MISEP 6.16 Supervisory Oversight (Commitment 66)
Section
Description Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on
the worker's caseload. Supervisors shall review and
approve each service plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statue Violation.
Type
Allegation There are concerns at the supervisory level in regard to the level
of support being offered to staff and clients as needed.
Investigation On 10/3/2022 I reviewed the complaint which indicated:
• Administrator 1 was supposed to be supervising staff, but
she would not come to the Port Huron office.
• Administrator 1 would send other supervisors, who did not
know the cases well, and would not help with a crisis.
• The agency hired a new director who has no training in
foster care.
• This happened between August and September 2022.
• No further clarification in the complaint.
The complainant was anonymous.
Administrator 1
Administrator 1 was interviewed by me via telephone on
10/5/2022 and onsite on 10/12/2022. She reported staff always
have a supervisor or director in the building. She reported some
staff work from home two days a week and are allowed to be in
the office three days. She reported when she took over oversight
of this site, they had a staffing storage. Two foster care
supervisors had resigned on 6/3/2022 and 6/23/2022, they were
down two foster care workers, and the site was without a program
director. She reported not withstanding that, the workers were
8

not without adequate and appropriate supervision. She reported
she was not always onsite, but Program Director (PD) XX, from
the Ennis- Monroe office and PD Y from the Ennis- Howell office
were filling in to cover the site and provide supervisory oversight.
She reported this is a small site and in addition to PD XX and PD
Y, coming on site to provide any needed staff support a couple of
times per week, there is also an adoption program manager and
licensing supervisor onsite daily. Administrator 1 reported the two
prior mentioned staff have been with the program three and five
years respectively, and they, as do, PD XX and PD Y have past
foster care experience and are/were able to provide staff support.
Administrator 1 denied her or the new chief administrator,
Administrator Z not having foster care experience. She provided a
copy of her and Administrator Z’s resumes.
Staff Interviews:
I interviewed Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4, Staff 5, and Staff 7 onsite on
10/12/2022. I interviewed Staff 6 by telephone while I was onsite
on 10/12/2022; and I interviewed Staff 8 by telephone on
10/17/2022.
All of the above-named staff interviewed affirmed Administrator 1’s
reporting related to PD XX, and PD Y coming to the agency
several times a week to ensure for daily supervisory coverage. A
couple of these staff also reported another supervisory staff,
Administrator ZZ would also fill in; and that Staff 10 the Adoption
Program was onsite and would provide supervision. They
indicated PD XX was onsite on Monday and Wednesday; PD Y on
Tuesday and Thursdays and Administrator 1 on Friday.
With the exception of Staff 4 and Staff 5 all other staff persons
interviewed reported feeling supported, not having a problem
obtaining supervision or obtaining assistance related to cases or
other foster care or adoption service needs.
• Staff 4 reported feeling supported and well supervised now.
She reported prior to her new supervisor she did feel she
was getting all that she needed from PD XX during the time
PD XX was temporarily assigned to supervise her. She
also felt she was not given enough assistance when she
had to go to a shelter to deal with a youth who had been
disruptive. She acknowledged that PD XX and another
supervisor did come to the shelter to relieve her. Staff 4 did
not report there being a time that she was not provided at
least monthly supervision.
• Staff 5 denied there being a time she personally felt
unsupported or was without needed or required
9

supervision. She reported knowing that Staff 4 had felt
unsupported. Staff 5 said as an adoption worker she
shared some cases with Staff 4 and Staff 4 had expressed
concerns in this area due to some difficult cases. Staff 5
reported she offered assistance and help to Staff 4. Staff 5
expressed optimism that all will be better now that they
have a supervisor directly for the Port Huron site.
Documents Reviewed:
• MISACWIS case records, for eight of the 45 cases listed on
the caseload list provided to me, with respect to monthly
worker/supervisor supervision meetings. No areas of
noncompliance were observed related in this standard.
• A copy of a resume for Administrator 1, which showed she
has past experience as a foster care worker, supervised
independent living worker, program coordinator and child
welfare program director.
• A copy of a resume for Administrator Z, which showed she
has past experience as a family’s first counselor, foster
care worker, adoption resource consultant, and licensing
worker.
Analysis There is insufficient evidence to support the allegation as
indicated in the complaint or to show a lack of supervisory
oversight.
Conclusion Violation Not Established.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Continuation of the agency’s current licensing status is recommended.
